portfolio.title: My Work
portfolio.description: I’m a Full Stack Designer who creates high-quality digital products to help businesses and their users achieve their goals. With my background in design and programming, I serve as a bridge between users, designers, and developers. I approach every problem with empathy, curiosity, and positivity to find a win-win solution.

resume.title: Resume
resume.description: Read about my resume below. Whether you are a fellow tech ethusiast or recruiter, I'd love to connect and explore how we might collaborate!

about.title: Connect with Me
about.description: When I'm not working, I enjoy listening to audio books, playing word puzzles and going on food adventures. You can also find me on the tennis court during summer, ski slopes during winter, or climbing gyms all year round.

projectData.projectName: Trane Supply Products & Parts Search Site
projectData.projectDescription: Design an e-commerce search experience that helps business agents and customers efficiently find the products or parts and put together orders across Salesforce and Yext platform.
projectData.projectProblem: With millions of products offered by the buisiness, accessing product information was a cumbersome process. Agents must have a precise knowledge of where to look and navigate through multiple databases and platforms, manually connecting the dots to find the right information. The goal of the project is to transform its e-commerce site and streamline the part-finding process so it provides a effortless shopping experience for both HVAC agents and customers.
myResponsibilities: Developed userflow for user stories and built high-fidelity designs for over 10 product features
Collaborated with the client team and Yext engineers to develop technical solutions
Worked with Trane UX researchers to conduct usability testing
Led internal design brainstorming sessions

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Trane has a variety of user types, with different goals that lead to different product needs.
blockBulletPoints: Remote agents who interact with customers over the phone
Storefront agents who engage with customers in person
HVAC professionals or companies who purchase parts from Trane.
Unauthenticated customers interested in purchasing parts from Trane
Product information was hosted in separate databases and on different platforms. Agents had to log into multiple platforms and connect the dots manually to find the product they are looking for.
This clunky setup requires an agent to have extensive and percise knowledge of where each piece of data is located and how to find them.
To gain deeper market insights, we also conducted a competitive analysis of direct competitors
We identified common layouts and design patterns across their competitors.
Starting with user stories, the entire project team met to gather business requirements, discuss user needs, business goals, and define the technical details for upcoming features.
Outlined and crafted user flows chart for each user story.
Presented user flows with hifi mockups to shareholders
Collaborated closely with engineers and project managers to define the scope, discuss technical solutions, and identify potential challenges.
As more design mockups are designed, I have regular check-ups with engineers to seek alignment
Led and participated brainstorming sessions
Empowered our four-member design team to address challenging design requests and generate design solutions.
Worked with client's UX researchers to design user feedback questions
Participated in usability study sessions to test out hi-fidelity mockups with end users
In 2024, our enhanced search platform handled over 9.4 million searches.
To streamline and simplify the product-finding journey, we created a search experience that consolidates related information from multiple databases into a single, cohesive web interface.
Reduced the time it takes for agents and customers to find products parts.

projectData.projectDescription: Create 6 website templates that help hundreds of dentists partners maintain their digital presence and create analytics dashboard to help Heartland marketing team improve site and listing performances.
projectData.projectProblem: Managing a dental practice involves numerous responsibilities. Effective marketing is a crucial aspect. However, these non-dental-related tasks can often divert dentists' attention from their primary focus—caring for patients. The project aims to help hundreds of dentists Heartland partners reduce their workload of maintaining their digital presence.
myResponsibilities: Led brainstorming sessions with the client team to align on design requirements and explore branding applications for the front-end
Collaborated with the client to identify practical platform solutions tailored to their marketing team’s workflow
Developed high-fidelity mockups for six templates, each featuring seven unique pages
Integrated Figma variables into mockups, ensuring that live pages meet WCAG standards, regardless of branding colors

infoBlocks.blockDescription: There are multiple stakeholders to consider in the design process, each benefiting from various aspects of the solution:
blockBulletPoints: Patients, who are browsing the sites for a new dentist or booking follow-up visits with their existing providers
Dentists, who seek greater customization options for content on their sites
Heartland teams, who are active managing dentists' listsings and websites
To gain a deeper understanding of business operations, requirements, and goals, participated in multiple requirements sessions with the client team.
I led brainstorming sessions with the client's key contacts to clearly define the problem, identify technical challenges, and develop a comprehensive solution.
I mapped out user flows to visualize the process of launching a new site within the platform.
Using the client-provided design brief, the design team and I created distinct style guides for each template, defining typography and color usage.
I collaborated with developers to dynamically mapping content and color variables to the templates, customizing them for each dental office's branding.
To ensure the templates can work with various branding colors without code change, I created Figma variables to test color application, accessibility, and dark mode functionality.
To highlight data variability to developers while minimizing the number of components, I carefully organized, defined, and reused design components
Developed high-fidelity mockups and implemented a scalable file structure for long-term maintainability.
I led design competitive analysis sessions to gain insights into market trends.
To quickly generate and explore design ideas, I facilitated wireframing sessions with other designers
We successfully launched over 1,700 dentist websites using five of the six available templates.
In 2024, the dental office sites collectively garnered 3.94 million views.
In the same year, the websites generated over 172,000 appointment bookings, indicating that 4.3% of users chose to book an appointment through the site.

projectData.projectName: Merrill Bank of America Financial Advisor Pages Redesign & Dashboard
projectData.projectDescription: Revamp Merrill Bank of America's advisor pages to help prospective customers learn more about Bank of America advisors while creating platform solution that enables bank advisors to efficiently manage the content on their personal pages.
projectData.projectProblem: Merrill leverages the Yext platform to efficiently manage thousands of financial advisor listings and web pages. With three distinct lines of business, each requiring tailored branding and specifications, the team is developing a series of page templates and a content management dashboard. This solution will showcase each advisor’s financial services while empowering them to effortlessly manage their website content.
myResponsibilities: Analyzed website traffic data to identify user patterns and optimize design decisions.
Developed a scalable component library adaptable for multiple brands.
Designed high-fidelity page templates for 3 distinct lines of business.
Collaborated with project managers and developers to scope projects and brainstorm platform solutions.
Improved upon an existing custom dashboard solution for efficient site content management

infoBlocks.blockDescription: There are multiple stakeholders to consider in the design process:
blockBulletPoints: Customers, who are browsing the sites for a perspective advisors or contacting their existing advisors
Advisors who want to market themselves to prospective customers and manage the content on their personal or team sites.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Website Traffic Analysis & Google PageSpeed Insights
blockBulletPoints: Scroll analysis revealed that over 60% of visitors don’t reach 25% of the advisor page, making above-the-fold content critical.
Jumplink navigation drives the most traffic.
'Contact Us' and 'Request Appointment' CTAs, which lead to similar forms, are the most frequently used.
Customers are especially drawn to advisors with awards and accolades.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: I conducted a UX audit of the advisor page and identified several issues:
blockBulletPoints: Users experienced a few seconds of a blank screen during their first visit. Google PageSpeed Insights confirmed high First Contentful Paint times on both desktop and mobile.
It takes 8-10 scrolls to reach the bottom of the page. Several text-heavy sections  are making the page longer, contributing to low engagement at the bottom.
Hero designs feature large images that push advisor names and addresses below the fold.
Background images with overlaid text or additional images in multiple sections reduced readability and sometimes obscured advisors' headshots.
Many advisors have busy schedules and prefer a mix of well-written boilerplate content and customizable sections on their pages
Team portraits can vary in size and aspect ratio, so advisors want several hero design options to accommodate these differences.
Some accolades are awarded to individual advisors, while others are given to the entire team. Advisors want to showcase both types of recognition on their pages.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the data insight, we devised a redesign plan with the following improvement:
blockBulletPoints: Condense content by uitilizing tabbed section and carousel on the page to reduce page length.
Combine the “Contact Us” and “Request Appointment” calls-to-action into a single, prominent CTA to enhance user engagement.
Update the section showcasing advisors' accolades for better visibility.
Apply web development best practices, such as reducing image sizes, to improve page speed.
I developed and presented wireframes to the client to confirm content placement and user experience for the advisor pages.
To ensure the content customization is feasible within the platform, I collaborated closely with project managers and engineers throughout this process.
To manage complex data variations and minimize redundancy in development, I curated reusable design components for different templates and breakpoints.
I regularly referenced the client’s branding guideline to ensure the new pages can integrate seamlessly into their existing ecosystem.
Throughout the process, our project team met with the client every week to gather feedback and improve the designs.

refineDesign.sectionDescription: When I joined the project, the dashboard was already in use by advisors. Some advisors needed to create new teams with colleagues to serve customers collaboratively. Previously, this required contacting Yext to set up a new team site. To streamline this process, the project team decided to implement a site creation wizard, allowing advisors to easily create their own sites

infoBlocks.blockDescription: I met with project manager to clarify any outstanding questions regarding the user goals and established business processes:
blockBulletPoints: To create a site, the team owner has to find and add other advisor.
They need to provide a profile information for the new team
After submiting the request, the team creation goes through an approval process.
Once a team is created, advisors cannot delete the team.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the requirements, I drafted users flow to serve as a foundation for the high-fidelity mockups.

Using the user flow, I created high-fidelity mockups and interactive prototypes in Figma. The project team then walked the client through the prototype to gather feedback and identify further opportunities for design improvement.

blockBulletPoints: Our team successfully launched 15000+ advisors sites.
Reduced page length by over 50%, optimizing content through efficient UI patterns and minimizing scroll.
Increased 'Contact Us' form completion rate by 50%.

projectData.projectName: The UPS Store Mircrosite & Search Redesign
projectData.projectDescription: Revamp the UPS Store Microsite template including the location page, service page and search site to streamline the user experience, minimizing friction in the UI and enhancing navigation.
projectData.projectProblem: The UPS Store currently hosts its locatiomn microsites on Yext Platform. Each location includes a homepage and a set of location-specific service pages. Although the site has performed steadily over the past few years, The UPS Store is now looking for opportunities to enhance the site and improve the user experience.
myResponsibilities: Examined the UPS Store search site using heuristic evaluation and web analytics
Conducted user testing on the UPS Store search site
Built audit reports based on the user testing result
Provided design recommendations based on the report insights

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Location Microsite UX Audits & Competitive Analysis
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the location microsite, our team conducted an in-house competitive analysis. The UPS team also provided us with a third-party heuristic audit.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Search Site UX Audits & Usability Testing
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the search site, our team conducted an in-house site analytics, usability testing, and heuristic audit of the search site.

blockBulletPoints: The inbound site navigation is confusing to users. Multiple header links lead to the same page content.
The complete list of services offered at each location is buried lower on the page. As a result, customers have difficulties figuring out whether a location offer a specific service.
The site branding differs significantly from the brand’s main domain UPS.com

The search result only returns information about the current UPS store. This scope of the search, however, is not obvious to users. Customers are searching for non-location-specific information such as store finders or career at UPS
No-result screens are sometimes unhelpful. Search UI would state that filtering to another topic will return a matching result when we know the database doesn’t contain the relevant content.
The lack of search loading indication prompts users to refresh the page, especially at a slower page load speed.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the data insight, I worked with another designer to devise a redesign plan with the following improvement:
blockBulletPoints: Analyzing search data showed that users typically seek services near their physical location. To accommodate this behavior, we expanded the search scope to display results beyond a single location, prioritizing services closest to the user. We also introduced a 'My Store' button, automatically set to the nearest location, enabling users to refine search results based on their preferred store.
To improve site navigation, we repositioned the breadcrumbs above the header, clearly indicating that the content on the site is specific to the current UPS office.

We revamped the above-the-fold desig  to make accessing services easier. Users can now quickly find relevant services with a single click on the 'Services' Tab without needing to scroll through the entire page.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: I updated the design based on our insights. Our project team then met with the client every week to gather feedback and improve the designs.

blockBulletPoints: Identified key areas for UX improvement on the page.
Built trust with the client by understanding their business needs and design requirements.

projectData.projectDescription: Create Figma templates and component repository that empower designers to efficiently craft custom dashboard designs while ensuring consistency and standardization across the board.
projectData.projectProblem: With the influx of dashboard projects, designers frequently start each design file from scratch, leading to inefficiencies, inconsistencies across designs, and maintenance challenges. The goal is to create a Figma template and component repository that empowers designers to efficiently craft custom dashboard designs while ensuring consistency and standardization across the board.
myResponsibilities: Conducted user research to gather insights
Turned user insights into design actions
Developed a comprehesive design template and component library
Collected feedback on the update template

infoBlocks.blockDescription: To gain deeper insights into the current dashboard building experience and reduce my designer bias, I interviewed four other designers:
blockBulletPoints: 2 new hires who has been with the company for less than 1 year
2 tenured colleagues who have been with the company for over 1 year

infoBlocks.blockHeading: The interview was designed to answer the following questions
blockBulletPoints: What is their current workflow when it comes to designing the dashboard?
What are their painpoints when it comes to building a dashboard design?
What are some examples of dashboard they’ve built recently?
Building from ground zero or relying on previous examples to set up design files
Junior designers are often unfamiliar with the platform's capabilities and unsure whether a component is available out-of-the-box or needs to be custom-designed
Designers often need to manipulate screenshots by cropping, covering, or combining images to save time.
Audited existing client dashboard examples and compiled a list of common modules used across designs.
Improve file organization by grouping components based on the functionality of the modules.
Consulted with the product team to identify opportunities for aligning our designs with their design systems
Consulted with engineers to understand each module's customizability during development and integrated them into the components.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Once I built out the first draft of the component library, I went on to test the template with the same set of designers. I asked them to complete the following tasks:
blockBulletPoints: Review the Entire File: Provide an initial impression based on the overall organization, clarity, and usability of the file.
Find a Specific Module: Locate a specific module using only its name to assess ease of navigation
Inspect Customizable Modules: Evaluate the customizable modules and provide initial feedback on their flexibility and ease of use.
Participants appreciated that the page layout resembles other files we use.
They found the dashboard mockup page overwhelming due to the numerous modules displayed on a single page.
Participants requested additional descriptions or annotations next to the components to aid the navigation of the file.
They had differing opinions on how to organize and manage modules after a custom dashboard is built, such as whether to delete unused modules or save them for future use.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Based on feedback, I incorporated the following changes to the template
blockBulletPoints: Separated the three sets of modules into different Figma pages to reduce information overload.
Added descriptions on each page to help designers, particularly new hires, become familiar with the platform's capabilities.
Included annotations to explain complex components and how to use them.
The Figma template and component repository significantly reduced the time needed to build custom dashboards.
Experienced designers can now focus on creating intuitive in-platform experiences for our customers, rather than building components from scratch
New hires can get started quickly, relying less on tenured designers for guidance.

projectData.projectDescription: Design a mobile app that helps non-profit organizers more effectively track and manage notes, contacts and to-dos.
projectData.projectProblem: Non-profit organizers frequently juggle multiple cases simultaneously. They engage with community members through door-to-door interactions, gathering notes and contact details on the spot. Often relying on paper, pen, or simple phone apps for documentation, these methods can quickly become disorganized and inefficient over time, making it difficult to manage and retrieve important information.
myResponsibilities: Conducted user research
Developed personas and empathy maps, user stories
Proritized MVP app features and created initial userflow

infoBlocks.blockDescription: To better understand our users, we conducted Zoom interviews with three non-profit organizers to better understand their current workflow. The interview was designed to answer the following questions:
blockBulletPoints: What does their day-to-day look like?
What pain points do they encounter in their job responsibilities?
What tools are they currently using?
What do they like and dislike about those tools?

Organizers frequently find it challenging to take notes while engaging with community members. As a result, note-taking is often deferred until after the conversation, leading to a rushed and potentially incomplete capture of information.
Some community members don't speak fluent English, leading to communication barriers and misunderstandings.
Organizers frequently manage multiple cases over extended periods, making it difficult to update statuses, organize notes, and track to-dos efficiently.
When cases are handed off between organizers, disorganized notes can result in a lack of context and delays in service delivery.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the interview, we created 3 user persona to help empathize with our users.Each persona represents a unique sets of user needs.
We also built user empathy maps for different stages of a organizer's work flow. This helped us separate user painpoints into themes.

blockBulletPoints: Based on the insights we gathered, we developed user stories using Ad-lib.
We discussed and ranked user stories to prioritize the app features for the MVP.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: With insight from the research, we moved into the beginning stage of the design phrase.
blockBulletPoints: We outlined essential user flow through breadboarding
The breadboard helped define necessary screens for each features.
The research gave us valuable insights into organizers' processes and pain points.
It directly shaped how we prioritized app features to create an effective MVP.

projectData.projectDescription: Built custom review generation email & landing page templates based on multiple user scenarios.
projectData.projectProblem: Allstate seeks to boost agent review generation through an email campaign. Our design team was tasked with creating a Custom Reviews solution by designing and building Review Generation Email templates and Collection Landing Page templates.
